name: Coahuilteco
imgAlt: A General region of where the Coahuilteco Tribe existed and spread there language
description: Coahuilteco was spoken across southern Texas and northeastern Coahuila by small, mobile hunter‑gatherer groups. It went extinct in the 19th century after missionization, disease, and forced assimilation fragmented its communities. The language is poorly documented, and its classification remains uncertain, making revival impossible today.

name: Toboso
imgAlt: Image of the Toboso people.
description: The Toboso language belonged to the Indigenous peoples of northern Chihuahua and Coahuila. Spanish campaigns, mission life, and displacement led to its disappearance by the late 1700s. Only scattered word lists survive, leaving no viable path for revival.

name: Karankawa
imgAlt: Image of what the Karankawan tribe might have looked like
description: Karankawa was spoken along the Texas Gulf Coast by coastal fishing peoples. Epidemics, warfare, and settler expansion caused its decline, and the last speakers died in the 19th century. A few vocabulary lists exist, but not enough for reconstruction.

name: Jumano
imgAlt: Map of the original homeland of the Jumano people
description: The Jumano people were widespread traders across Texas, New Mexico, and northern Mexico, but their language is unknown. No surviving vocabulary exists, and scholars cannot classify it. Because it was never recorded, revival is not possible.

name: Guamares
imgAlt: map of different tribes that worked together including the Guamares
description: The Guamares of Guanajuato spoke a language now completely lost. They resisted Spanish rule fiercely, and their population collapsed through warfare and assimilation in the 1500s. No linguistic data survives, making the language unrecoverable.

name: Caxcán
imgAlt: Caxcan warriors battling against the Spaniards
description: Caxcán was spoken in Zacatecas and Jalisco by the Caxcanes, central figures in the Mixtón War. After their defeat, forced resettlement and cultural suppression erased the language by the 1600s. No documentation survives.

name: Tecuexe
imgAlt: Tecuexe Masks from a museum in Zacatecas, Mexico near la Quemada.
description: The Tecuexe language of Jalisco and Los Altos vanished after intense colonial pressure and population decline. Only a few place names remain, leaving no usable linguistic record for revival.

name: Manso
imgAlt: The Mission to the Manso was established by Spanish missionaries in 1659. The mission built by the Manso still exists and is located in downtown Ciudad Juarez, Mexico.
description: The Manso people lived around present‑day El Paso and northern Chihuahua. Missionization and intermarriage led to the loss of their language by the early 1800s. No vocabulary was recorded.

name: Cuitlatec
imgAlt: Image of the last Cuitlateco Speakers
description: Cuitlatec was spoken in Guerrero and is one of Mexico’s most mysterious languages. The last speaker died in the 1960s. Only a small vocabulary and grammar sketch survive, not enough for revival.

name: Tepuztec
imgAlt: Image of what looks like pottery from the Tepuztec
description: Tepuztec, spoken in Michoacán, disappeared early in the colonial period. It is known only from brief missionary notes, and its classification is uncertain. No revival is possible

name: Cuyuteco
imgAlt: All towns that belonged to the Cututeco people are in clear Circles
description: Cuyuteco was spoken in Colima and Jalisco. It declined rapidly after Spanish conquest and assimilation policies. Only a few words survive, leaving the language effectively unreconstructable.

name: Totorame
imgAlt: Map of a bunch of tribs on the west coast of Mexico, where Totorame's trib is located at the very bottom of the image
description: The Totorame language of Nayarit and Sinaloa vanished in the 1700s after epidemics and mission life disrupted their communities. Documentation is minimal, preventing revival.

name: Xochimilco
imgAlt: Map of other tribs that could have spoken the original language of Nahuatl
description: Xochimilco was a Nahuatl‑related language spoken in the Valley of Mexico. It faded as Classical Nahuatl and Spanish replaced local varieties. Some vocabulary survives, but the distinct dialect is extinct.

name: Cholulteca
imgAlt: Pyramid of the Cholulteac people
description: Cholulteca was the local language of Cholula before Nahuatl dominance. It disappeared early in the colonial era, and almost nothing was recorded. Its family affiliation remains unknown.

name: Pochutec
imgAlt: Image of where Pochutec was spoken
description: Pochutec was a divergent branch of the Uto‑Aztecan family spoken in Oaxaca. It went extinct in the early 20th century. A small corpus exists, but not enough for full revival.

name: Ch'olti’
imgAlt: Portion of a Mayan hieroglyphic text in Palenque
description: Ch’olti’ was a colonial-era Mayan language spoken in Guatemala and Chiapas. It disappeared in the 18th century as communities shifted to other Mayan languages. Because it was documented by missionaries, scholars can partially reconstruct it, but full revival is unlikely.

name: Pericú
imgAlt: Map where the Pericú people used to live
description: Pericú was spoken at the southern tip of Baja California. Epidemics and missionization caused its collapse by the late 1700s. Only a few word lists survive, making revival impossible.

name: Guaycura
imgAlt: Map of where the Guaycura used to live
description: Guaycura, spoken in central Baja California Sur, went extinct in the 19th century. It is poorly documented and unrelated to nearby languages. No revival is possible.

name: Lost language of Teotihuacan
imgAlt: An image of Teotihuacan
description: The language of Teotihuacan remains unidentified. It may have been Totonacan, Mixe‑Zoquean, or something entirely unknown. Because no inscriptions survive, the language cannot be reconstructed.

name: Olmec
imgAlt: Area where the Olmec used to live
description: The Olmec likely spoke an early Mixe‑Zoquean language. It disappeared thousands of years ago as cultures shifted and diversified. Only reconstructed proto‑forms exist, not enough for revival.

name: Chicomuceltec
imgAlt: Image of Chapas Mexico, the area where Chicomuceltec was spoken
description: Chicomuceltec was a Mayan language spoken in Chiapas and Guatemala. It went extinct in the 18th century. A small vocabulary survives, but not enough for revival.

name: Garza
imgAlt: Present Day Grazan Tribe Leader
description: Garza was spoken in northeastern Mexico and southern Texas. It vanished in the 18th century after missionization and displacement. Only a handful of words were recorded.

name: Comecrudo
imgAlt: Some words in Comecrudo
description: Comecrudo was spoken along the lower Rio Grande by the Comecrudo people. It declined in the 1800s due to disease, displacement, and assimilation. A modest vocabulary survives, but not enough for full reconstruction.
